q: What conditions can psychiatrists treat?
a: Mental health conditions that may be diagnosed and treated by a psychiatrist include: anxiety and panic attacks, phobias, obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD), post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), personality disorders, schizophrenia, depression and bipolar disorder, dementia and Alzheimer's disease, eating disorders, sleep disorders, and addictions.

q: How can I get an appointment with a psychiatrist?
a: To see a psychiatrist on the NHS, a referral from your GP or another doctor is usually required. You can also see a psychiatrist privately, either through a referral from your GP or by contacting a psychiatric clinic directly or using online psychiatry services.

q: What happens during your appointments with a psychiatrist?
a: During your first appointment, your psychiatrist will carry out an initial assessment. They will ask about the problem that brought you to see them, general questions about your life and thoughts, and may also carry out a physical examination. After assessing your condition, they may prescribe medication or recommend other treatments such as counselling or cognitive behavioural therapy.

q: What areas of speciality do psychiatrists have?
a: Psychiatrists specialize in various areas including childhood and adolescent psychiatry, general adult psychiatry, older person's psychiatry, learning disabilities, and psychotherapy (talking therapies).

q: How can I find information about psychiatrists and their specialities?
a: You can check the medical register, a list of doctors in the UK, to find details of a psychiatrist, including their area of speciality. Psychiatrists who are current members of the Royal College of Psychiatrists will have the letters MRCPsych or FRCPsych after their name.

q: Where can I find further information and support about mental health?
a: The Royal College of Psychiatrists (RCPsych) provides mental health information in various areas, including problems and disorders, support and treatment, and advice for parents or carers and young people.

q: Can psychiatrists provide psychological support for people with physical health conditions?
a: Yes, psychiatrists may provide psychological support for people with long-term, painful, or terminal physical health conditions.

q: Do I need a referral to see a psychiatrist privately?
a: Most private psychiatrists prefer a referral from your GP. Your GP may be able to recommend psychiatrists in your area.

q: What treatments can psychiatrists recommend?
a: Psychiatrists can recommend various forms of treatment, including medication, counselling, and cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT).

q: How can community mental health services help manage mental illness?
a: Community mental health services work in small units or clinics and aim to help people manage their illness so they can lead a normal life within the community.

q: What are the main areas of expertise in psychiatry?
a: The main areas of expertise in psychiatry include childhood and adolescent psychiatry, general adult psychiatry, older person's psychiatry, learning disabilities, and psychotherapy.

q: What happens during the first appointment with a psychiatrist?
a: During your first appointment, your psychiatrist will carry out an initial assessment. They'll look at both your mental and physical health and may ask questions about the problem that brought you to see them.

q: What treatments can a psychiatrist recommend?
a: After assessing your condition, your psychiatrist may prescribe medication or recommend other treatments, such as counselling or cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT).

q: How many times do I need to see a psychiatrist?
a: The number of times you need to see a psychiatrist and the length of each appointment will depend on your circumstances.
